reasoning: The critique targets the essay’s section-3 optimism that (partial) AM-convergence plus moral trade/compromise can yield mostly-great futures. That’s an important pillar of the essay’s updated optimism, but not strictly necessary for the overall position (the essay is already quite uncertain/pessimistic about convergence and lists multiple blockers), so centrality is moderate. The point about endogenizing preferences under bargaining regimes (strategic preference adoption/signaling/commitment) is a real and under-discussed dynamic that could erode gains-from-trade and make optimistic equilibria unstable; however, it doesn’t fully refute the trade story because the essay already flags major frictions (power concentration, threats, bargaining dependence on outside options/institutions) and because mechanisms (credible commitment/verification, identity/utility observability constraints, institutional design) could partially mitigate the problem. The critique is mostly correct and clearly stated, focused on a single issue, with little extraneous content.
title: Strategic preference formation may destabilize the assumed gains from trade
